BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: A critical avalanche situation will be encountered over a wide area. The large quantity of fresh snow as well as the often large wind slabs can be released easily or naturally.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
A lot of new snow above approximately 2000 m.
Avalanches can be released and reach large size in isolated cases. This applies in particular on sunny slopes, as well as on wind-loaded slopes above approximately 2000 m. From starting zones that have retained some snow in these regions the avalanches can reach the valleys and in some places endanger transportation routes that are exposed.
At low and intermediate altitudes moist avalanches can penetrate even deep layers.
The conditions are very dangerous for backcountry touring.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area 100 to 150 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, fell in the last three days above approximately 2000 m. A lot of new snow in the high Alpine regions.
The sleet gave rise to a loss of strength within the snowpack over a wide area in particular at low and intermediate altitudes.

As a consequence of new snow and wind, sometimes large wind slabs formed.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather will be mostly sunny. These conditions will foster a gradual strengthening of the snowpack.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The fresh snow and the extensive wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: In particular in gullies and bowls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain easily released wind slabs will form. Skiers can release avalanches very easily, including large ones. Remotely triggered and natural avalanches are probable.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The snowfall gave rise to unfavourable bonding of the snowpack over a wide area in particular on steep slopes. The fresh wind slabs are difficult even for the trained eye to recognise and to be assessed with care and prudence.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: As a consequence of warming and solar radiation a considerable danger of dry and wet avalanches will persist in some regions.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation more medium-sized to large moist and wet avalanches are possible.
New snow and wind slabs can be released and reach medium size, especially in high Alpine regions.
The current avalanche situation calls for caution.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
60 to 80 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, fell in the last three days above approximately 2200 m. Up to 2000 m rain has fallen.
The surface of the snowpack will freeze to form a strong crust, after a clear night especially at low and intermediate altitudes. The sometimes large wind slabs of the last few days are bonding only slowly with the old snowpack. In addition the danger of dry and wet avalanches will increase as the day progresses.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The avalanche prone locations are difficult to recognise. Ski touring and other off-piste activities, including snowshoe hiking, call for defensive route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of wind from northwesterly directions, sometimes large wind slabs will form by Wednesday. Fresh and somewhat older wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in particular on very steep shady slopes. This applies in particular at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack, as well as adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.

Medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large natural avalanches are not ruled out. In particular on shady slopes the avalanches can penetrate even deep layers. In the typical avalanche paths the avalanches can in isolated cases still reach a long way.
As a consequence of solar radiation more moist and wet avalanches are possible in the afternoon. This applies in particular on very steep sunny slopes below approximately 2600 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
50 to 80 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Tuesday above approximately 2000 m. Here rain fell up to 2100 m.
The sometimes strong wind has transported the new snow significantly.
In some places new snow and wind slabs are lying on soft layers. The upper section of the snowpack is unfavourably layered.
The sleet gave rise to a loss of strength within the snowpack over a wide area at intermediate altitudes. Several medium-sized and large dry and wet avalanches have been released.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: As a consequence of warming during the day and the solar radiation, the likelihood of moist and wet avalanches being released will increase gradually in all altitude zones.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The avalanche prone locations are numerous. Ski touring and other off-piste activities, including snowshoe hiking, call for defensive route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of wind from northwesterly directions, sometimes large wind slabs will form by Wednesday. Fresh and somewhat older wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in particular on very steep shady slopes. This applies in particular at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack, as well as adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.

Medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large natural avalanches are possible. In particular on shady slopes the avalanches can penetrate even deep layers. In the typical avalanche paths the avalanches can as before reach a long way.
Afternoon: As a consequence of solar radiation more moist and wet avalanches are possible. This applies in particular on very steep sunny slopes below approximately 2600 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
60 to 100 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Tuesday above approximately 2000 m. Here rain fell up to 2200 m.
The sometimes strong wind has transported the new snow significantly.
In some places new snow and wind slabs are lying on soft layers. The upper section of the snowpack is unfavourably layered.
The sleet gave rise to a loss of strength within the snowpack over a wide area at intermediate altitudes. Numerous medium-sized and large dry and wet avalanches have been released until Monday, 1 April.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: As a consequence of warming during the day and the solar radiation, the likelihood of moist and wet avalanches being released will increase gradually in all altitude zones.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: A sometimes critical avalanche situation will prevail.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As the temperature drops only isolated moist loose snow avalanches are to be expected. On very steep grassy slopes more gliding avalanches are possible. Fresh and somewhat older wind slabs can be released easily by a single winter sport participant above the tree line. The prevalence of the avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: As a consequence of warming during the day avalanches are to be expected as the day progresses, even quite large ones.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The fresh wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence in all aspects. Wet snow requires caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The large quantity of fresh snow of the last few days and the wind slabs formed by the wind can be released by a single winter sport participant in all aspects above approximately 2200 m. Medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large avalanches are possible. At intermediate altitudes these can release the wet old snow as well. The prevalence of avalanche prone locations and likelihood of triggering will increase with altitude. As a consequence of warming during the day and the solar radiation, the likelihood of slab avalanches being released will increase in particular on sunny slopes.

On steep grassy slopes occasionally large gliding avalanches are possible. This applies especially on steep sunny slopes below approximately 2600 m, including on steep shady slopes below approximately 2200 m. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.
As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation numerous moist loose snow avalanches are to be expected as the day progresses, even medium-sized ones. This applies in particular on extremely steep sunny slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
A lot of snow fell in the last few days over a wide area. This applies in particular at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions. Fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are lying on soft layers in all aspects at elevated altitudes. The large quantity of fresh snow of the last few days and in particular the sometimes deep wind slabs are poorly bonded with the old snowpack in all aspects above approximately 2200 m.
The rain gave rise to thorough wetting of the snowpack below approximately 2200 m.
Outgoing longwave radiation during the night will be quite good over a wide area. The surface of the snowpack will freeze to form a strong crust only at high altitudes and will soften during the day. This applies in particular on sunny slopes at intermediate and high altitudes, as well as on shady slopes below approximately 2200 m.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence. Gliding snow requires caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The large quantity of fresh snow of the last few days as well as the sometimes deep wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in some cases in particular on northwest to north to southeast facing aspects above approximately 2400 m. In high Alpine regions these avalanche prone locations are present in all aspects. The prevalence of avalanche prone locations and likelihood of triggering will increase with altitude. Large avalanches are possible. At intermediate altitudes these can release the wet old snow as well.

On steep grassy slopes medium-sized to large gliding avalanches are possible. This applies especially on steep sunny slopes below approximately 2600 m, including on steep shady slopes below approximately 2400 m. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
A lot of snow fell in the last few days over a wide area. This applies in particular at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions.
Fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are lying on soft layers in all aspects at elevated altitudes. In some cases the various wind slabs have bonded still only poorly together.

Outgoing longwave radiation during the night will be quite good over a wide area. The surface of the snowpack will freeze to form a strong crust and will soften during the day. This applies in particular on sunny slopes at intermediate and high altitudes, as well as on shady slopes below approximately 2200 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Further decrease in danger of dry avalanches. As a consequence of rising temperatures the snow drift accumulations stabilised. Below approximately 2600 m: Gliding snow requires caution. The danger of moist avalanches will increase.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The fresh snow as well as the wind slabs formed during the snowfall must be evaluated with care and prudence.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The new snow and wind slabs of the last few days remain for the foreseeable future prone to triggering. The prevalence of the avalanche prone locations will increase as the day progresses. Such avalanche prone locations are to be found adjacent to ridgelines and on wind-loaded slopes. At higher altitudes large and, in isolated cases, very large avalanches are possible.
Avalanches can be released by a single winter sport participant.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The wind slabs have formed in particular adjacent to ridgelines and at elevated altitudes. The new snow and wind slabs of the last few days are poorly bonded with the old snowpack. The weather conditions gave rise to thorough wetting of the snowpack. Over a wide area new snow and wind slabs are lying on a wet old snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment:
Over a wide area continuous warming.
As a consequence of warming the avalanche prone locations will become more prevalent.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The fresh snow as well as the wind slabs formed during the snowfall must be evaluated with care and prudence.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The new snow and wind slabs of the last few days remain for the foreseeable future prone to triggering. The prevalence of the avalanche prone locations will increase as the day progresses. Such avalanche prone locations are to be found adjacent to ridgelines and on wind-loaded slopes. At higher altitudes large and, in isolated cases, very large avalanches are possible.
Avalanches can be released by a single winter sport participant.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The wind slabs have formed in particular adjacent to ridgelines and at elevated altitudes. The new snow and wind slabs of the last few days are poorly bonded with the old snowpack. The weather conditions gave rise to thorough wetting of the snowpack. Over a wide area new snow and wind slabs are lying on a wet old snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment:
Over a wide area continuous warming.
As a consequence of warming the avalanche prone locations will become more prevalent.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The fresh snow and the sometimes deep wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The fresh wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence in all aspects above approximately 2500 m. As a consequence of the precipitation medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large wet avalanches are possible below approximately 2500 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The sleet will give rise as the day progresses to rapid and thorough wetting of the old snowpack below approximately 2500 m. The fresh wind slabs are difficult even for the trained eye to recognise and to be assessed with care and prudence.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: As a consequence of a strong westerly wind, avalanche prone wind slabs will form. Fresh wind slabs are to be evaluated critically. Gliding snow requires caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Since Tuesday avalanche prone wind slabs will form adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. Avalanches can in some cases be released, even by a single winter sport participant and reach medium size. At intermediate altitudes these can release the wet old snow as well. The prevalence of avalanche prone locations and likelihood of triggering will increase with altitude.

On steep grassy slopes medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large gliding avalanches are possible. This applies especially on steep slopes below approximately 2600 m. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The fresh wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on northwest to north to east facing aspects at elevated altitudes. The older wind slabs of the weekend are now only very rarely prone to triggering.

Outgoing longwave radiation during the night will be quite good over a wide area. The surface of the snowpack will freeze to form a strong crust and will soften during the day. This applies in particular on sunny slopes at intermediate and high altitudes, as well as on shady slopes below approximately 2200 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: As a consequence of rising temperatures the snow drift accumulations stabilised. The danger of moist avalanches will increase.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The danger of moist and wet avalanches will increase during the day. In addition the wind slabs should be taken into account.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As the temperature drops only isolated moist loose snow avalanches are to be expected. On very steep grassy slopes more gliding avalanches are possible. Fresh and somewhat older wind slabs can be released easily by a single winter sport participant above the tree line. The prevalence of the avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: As a consequence of warming during the day avalanches are to be expected as the day progresses, in particular medium-sized ones.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs and wet snow require caution, especially at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh wind slabs can be released easily, but they can reach medium size, especially at intermediate and high altitudes.
As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation moist and wet avalanches are possible below approximately 2400 m.

The current avalanche situation calls for defensive route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area 40 to 60 cm of snow fell in the last three days above approximately 2200 m. A lot of new snow in the high Alpine regions. Up to 2000 m rain has fallen in some regions.
As a consequence of new snow and wind, sometimes avalanche prone wind slabs formed.

The surface of the snowpack will freeze to form a strong crust, after a clear night especially at low and intermediate altitudes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The sleet will give rise as the day progresses to rapid and thorough wetting of the old snowpack below approximately 1700 m.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The avalanche prone locations are very rare and are easy to recognise.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The old snowpack will be generally wet all the way through.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on shady slopes at intermediate and high altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Small and, in isolated cases, medium-sized avalanches are possible in particular on steep shady slopes. Avalanches can be released, in particular by large loads.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The weather conditions gave rise to thorough wetting of the snowpack. On sunny slopes hardly any snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Over a wide area continuous warming.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wet and gliding snow represent the main danger. Gliding snow is to be avoided.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of warming during the day small and, in isolated cases, medium-sized moist and wet avalanches are possible. In particular on steep grassy slopes gliding avalanches are possible. In addition the sometimes large wind slabs must be taken into account.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Outgoing longwave radiation during the night will be quite good. The surface of the snowpack will freeze to form a strong crust only at high altitudes. The spring-like weather conditions as the day progresses will give rise to increasing moistening of the snowpack. This applies in particular on sunny slopes at intermediate and high altitudes, as well as on shady slopes below approximately 2200 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The avalanche danger will persist. Low danger of gliding avalanches and moist snow slides will be encountered in some localities.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: On steep grassy slopes small to medium-sized gliding avalanches are possible. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Outgoing longwave radiation during the night will be quite good over a wide area. The surface of the snowpack will freeze to form a strong crust and will soften during the day. This applies in particular on sunny slopes at intermediate and high altitudes, as well as on shady slopes below approximately 2200 m.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wet snow slides and avalanches are possible in isolated cases. Mostly these are small.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Individual mostly small wet snow slides and avalanches are possible above approximately 1900 m. In gullies and bowls a sometimes precarious avalanche situation will be encountered in some localities.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Below approximately 1900 m hardly any snow is lying. The older wind slabs are to be found especially in gullies and bowls and at high altitudes.
